utterance.speaker: DANCER
utterance.content: Do you like that?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Uh...I don’t know.

utterance.speaker: DANCER
utterance.content: Do you want me to use my butt again?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I don’t know how I got here. How many drinks did I have?

utterance.speaker: DANCER
utterance.content: Your scotch hasn’t even arrived yet.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: That means I was drunk when I got here. 8:50. I remember being at work. I’ve lost at least four hours. Say five words.

utterance.speaker: DANCER
utterance.content: What do you mean?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: That’s four words. The accepted diagnostic test for global memory impairment is five random words.

utterance.speaker: DANCER
utterance.content: Are you okay?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I’m... Trying to find that out. Give me five... Animals.

utterance.speaker: DANCER
utterance.content: Um...Cat. Bird. Monkey. Rhino. Goldfish.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Monkey, Rhino... Either I’m massively drunk –

utterance.speaker: DANCER
utterance.content: Oh, you’re bleeding.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Or it’s someone else’s blood. Do you see a wound? How bad is it?

utterance.speaker: DANCER
utterance.content: It’s all over.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I have a concussion. Retrograde amnesia. I have no keys, no phone. I’ve been mugged.

utterance.speaker: DANCER
utterance.content: No you haven’t. You already gave me a twenty.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Did you earn it?

utterance.speaker: DANCER
utterance.content: Not yet.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Someone is going to die.

utterance.speaker: DANCER
utterance.content: Kenny!

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Not you. I saw something, a symptom. Someone is going to die unless I find them.

utterance.speaker: DANCER
utterance.content: Who?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I have no idea. Keep the change.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I saw somebody dying.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: You saw thirty people flying into glass and metal.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I saw a symptom before the crash.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: You're concussed. You don't know what you saw and you don't know when you saw it. A week ago, you noticed a symptom in a soap star.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Bad argument. Since I was right about that.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: But your brain obviously thinks it happened last night. Wires are crossed.

utterance.speaker: CAMERON
utterance.content: That's all of it. A few stitches will hold your brain in place.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Ow!

utterance.speaker: CAMERON
utterance.content: Hey! Hold your head still unless you want me to sew your nose under your eye.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Why was I taking the bus?

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Because you were drunk.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: What if I saw someone and I followed them on from... Somewhere in Princeton?

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: You okay?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Perfect. Uh...Uh...You. Get histories from everyone in here.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Did you just forget his name?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: No. Lesbian. Find out if anybody on that bus was taken to other hospitals.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: You just forgot mine.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: No, Thirteen. I just wanted to call you a lesbian.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: I'm not a lesbian.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I was rounding up, from 50%. Find my cane and motorcycle. Figure out where I went last night.

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: Where’s your cane and motorcycle? And where’d you go last night?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You’re going to trust me? I lie about everything.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: How much bigger could it get?

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: You don’t think it's – A little weird that there’s both a giant crash and a simultaneous, mysterious symptom sighting?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: What if it’s not a coincidence?

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: You mean like the hand of God reaching down and screwing with you?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: That... Or the symptom caused the crash. Did you see anybody in a bus driver’s uniform?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Right here. Purpura on Ralph Klamden’s neck, indicative of leukaemia. Caused a bleed in the brain, and hence the accident.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Indicative of wearing a seatbelt. It’s just a bruise.

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: I have leukaemia?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: No, we just ruled that out, pay attention. He probably had a seizure.

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: I didn’t have a seizure. I got hit by a garbage truck.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Which you drove into while you were seizing.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: You saw the bus driver exhibiting the initial stages of a seizure and didn’t bother telling him to pull over?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Hey! Nobody leaves here until I say they can be discharged.

utterance.speaker: WHEELCHAIR GUY
utterance.content: She said I was –

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Is she me? You have a fever.

utterance.speaker: WHEELCHAIR GUY
utterance.content: No, I’m fine.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I need him to stay.

utterance.speaker: NURSE
utterance.content: Pulse is normal. BP’s normal. Everything’s normal.

utterance.speaker: WHEELCHAIR GUY
utterance.content: I just have a stiff neck from the crash.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Stiff neck. This man has meningitis. We need to quarantine the whole ER. No one leaves here until their full workup is complete.

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: You left here at 5:23 p.m. Your motorcycle never made it home.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Well, that covers ten seconds out of the four hours I can’t remember. Where else did you look?

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: We did pull up a list of all of the injuries. Twenty-two victims were brought here, injuries ranging from a broken pelvis to a severed right foot.

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: The other eight were taken over to Princeton General.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: It would be helpful if these came with head shots and resumes.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: Twenty-something year-old Jane Doe. Kidney contusion, laceration on her leg –

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Both of which are expected complications when someone goes from 60 to 0 in no seconds flat.

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: The weirdest thing we’ve got is a ruptured spleen.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Okay, new plan. We make a list of all the bars between here and the crash site. Find out where I went, we go there –

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: On it.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You’re not going to do anything, are you?

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: We’re going to go to the ER and do our jobs.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Someone is dying because I can’t remember –

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: When you remember, you can page us.

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: The shortest distance between here and your memory is straight through your prefrontal cortex. All we have to do is access it.

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: Great idea. I’ll build the giant submarine. You get the miniaturization gizmo.

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: Medical hypnosis can bring the brain to a class II theta state, increasing focus and memory retrieval.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You’re not doing to make me do the chicken dance, are you?

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: Someone on the surgical department must be trained.

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: Just relax. Keep letting go of any intrusive thoughts.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: So what, you saw an ad on the back of a comic book?

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: Shh… I did a rotation in Melbourne. Focus on the sound of your breath.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: You're taxing an already injured brain. It’s like telling him to walk it off after a broken ankle.

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: Wilson is done talking now. Visualize the bus. The way it looked. The way it smelled. The people on it. What they look like.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: This is a waste of... Time. Cool.

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: Focus on the details.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: The bus is empty.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Is this really working?

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: Shh. Just focus. Clear your mind. Think back to how you felt. Details you saw.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I can't see out the windows, and I can see you guys.

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: Memories further from the incident should be clearer. Where were you before you got on the bus?

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Why did you get so drunk at five in the afternoon, alone?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I need a reason? God, I hate 'beer' brand beer.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: When he's hypnotized, can he lie?

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: He...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I can be mistaken, but I can't actually lie under hypnosis.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Is he lying?

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: What are you running away from?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: When I'm drinking without you? What am I running away from? Hmm, One of those imponderables. Can you hold off on your insecurities until we find this patient?

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: Do you see anyone in the bar?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I see a faceless crowd. How do I focus? Say something to make me focus.

utterance.speaker: AMBER
utterance.content: He's concerned about you. Why does that mean he's insecure?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Will you get your girlfriend out of here?

utterance.speaker: AMBER
utterance.content: It's a legit question.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Amber's there? You've got Amber in your head?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You put her in my head. I can't even have a conversation with you in my subconscious without her tagging along.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Well she better have her clothes on.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Unfortunately. I didn't mean to say that out loud.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Say what out loud?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I didn't say it out loud? Nothing.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: What's going on in there?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: If I can't lie, I need these two out of here.

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: Let's just ignore Wilson and Amber for now, shall we?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I wish it were that – That's some program they got down there in Melbourne. Cheers. I remember the bartender.

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: Good. Now you're accessing your temporal lobe. Does the bartender have any odd symptoms?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: He seems fine. Anybody here sick? Anyone here taking the bus?

utterance.speaker: BARTENDER
utterance.content: You are.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Because... You took my keys.

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: Good. This is good. Now we can retrace your steps. Let's go back to the bus. What's in front of you?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Passengers.

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: Anything, special about them?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Some emo guitar hero wannabe.

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: You're focusing on him, why?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Because nose picking could mean nasal pruritus. He's dying.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You a nose picker?

utterance.speaker: EMO GUY
utterance.content: Do I have to answer?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: If the answer was no, you would have answered. Tilt your head back.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: He’s fine. He doesn’t even have meningitis, just like everybody else we’ve had to give meningitis shots to. You can go.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You have a brain tumour.

utterance.speaker: EMO GUY
utterance.content: You’re kidding, right?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: If I was kidding, I’d be dressed like you.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: You’re fine. A nurse will sign you out.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Go home. Have fun. Relax. I’m probably just a nut case.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Tilt your head back.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You can get your things and go.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: You need to rest. I’m admitting you.

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: Oh! Oh! I can’t get up. I can’t move my legs.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Your legs are not your biggest problem. Your biggest problem is... I don’t know what your biggest problem is.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: So, we have the who, but not the what.

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: We’ve only got one symptom to go on. Sudden onset paralysis.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: We actually have two symptoms.

utterance.speaker: FOREMAN
utterance.content: Only one that we remember.

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: You did a full work up on the guy. Did you find anything?

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: CT ruled out subdural hematoma, stroke, or subarachnoid hemorrhage.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: Guillain-Barré fits.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I’m just trying to figure out what Guillain-Barré looks like.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: You can’t just eliminate everything because it doesn’t match what you might have seen.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: How about because it doesn’t match what I could have seen? Guillain-Barré has no external physical manifestations.

utterance.speaker: FOREMAN
utterance.content: Everything has some external physical manifestations, and you’re obsessive enough to notice any of them. Which means there’s nothing we can rule out.

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: Elevated white count means transverse myelitis is...

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: Sudden paralysis while driving a bus. That’s the sort of subtle clue that only a genius would have noticed.

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: Are you sure you’re feeling okay?

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: To smell a bus, obviously.

utterance.speaker: FOREMAN
utterance.content: Yeah, I’ll uh, start him on antibiotics in case it’s transverse myelitis. You guys go sniff a city bus.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: Why are you smelling the passengers’ clothes?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Smell is the most powerful evokerater of memory. I need to get back on that bus.

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: Okay. So why are you taking so much Vicodin?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: If Cuddy asks, blocking the pain helps focus the memory.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: You split your head open, you should rest. Anything?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: A hint of... Exploded bus.

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: House, that’s four Vicodin in forty seconds. At this rate...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Wish me luck. I’m going in. Rambo style.

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: House, do you think this is going to work, or are you just stoned?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Both, apparently.

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: You’re wrong. It’s not working.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: So, you’re saying I’m not here.

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: If this were a real memory, you’d be limping. And you wouldn’t be talking to me. I’m obviously a hallucination.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Okay. So I went a little heavy on the Vicodin.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: We’re both in my head. You’d think one of us would have noticed the blood.

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: Why haven’t you had a head CT yet?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Who do you want me to treat? Me or you? Did you have a seizure?

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: Dumb question. The brain’s too fried during a seizure to form memories.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Dumb answer. I wasn’t asking you, I was asking me. Because you’ve already proven that you're not here.

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: I’m getting a headache.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Is that a clue?

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: Again, I’m not here. You’re getting a headache. Stop arguing with a hallucination and get some treatment.

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: He can’t. The hallucination is your messed up brain’s way of reasoning out a problem.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You weren’t on the bus.

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: How do you know?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Five hundred dollar shoes. Not on a Princeton cross-town.

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: Must be another reason why I’m here.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Yes. What do you have to tell me? I was talking to the passengers on the bus!

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: You were hallucinating. You’re getting an MRI.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Stop fidgeting.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: If you haven’t found the bleed yet, it can’t be –

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: There’s edema, and localized swelling in the section of the temporal lobe that controls short-term memory. Also, the penis size cortex is set to pathetic. What didn’t you say out loud?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Very little.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: When you were under hypnosis, you were talking to Amber?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I wanted to see her naked.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Seriously, what were you hiding?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I want to see her naked.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: You want to see everyone naked. Why would you hide that?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Well some guys get upset when you objectify their girlfriends. But if you’re okay, I’ve got a digital video camera. So we could –

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Why would I be upset that you’re treating my girlfriend like you treat every other woman on the planet, unless...You’re not? Unless it’s deeper than that. You WEREN'T objectifying her.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Trust me. I want to do some very nasty, demeaning stuff to your girlfriend.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: You have feelings for her. This is bad.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: It’s a longitudinal fracture of the temporal bone.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I banged my head.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: This isn’t just a boo-boo.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I’ll rest once I’ve figured out what’s wrong with this guy.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Why? Why this guy? You want patients with weird undiagnosed symptoms? You get five files like that on your desk every morning and you’d never risk your life for them. Why is this guy so special, so that you become Batman?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I don’t know.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Maybe it’s because you have a cracked skull, and you’re not yourself. Go home. Go to sleep.

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: My legs are holding.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: Good, now put all your weight on your right leg. The antibiotics are working. It’s TM.

utterance.speaker: FOREMAN
utterance.content: It’s two in the morning. You should be home resting what’s left of your bruised brain.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Recovery’s too fast.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: What, the fact that he’s getting better is evidence that we’re wrong?

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: I need to sit.

utterance.speaker: FOREMAN
utterance.content: Recovery slow enough for you now?

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: It’s my stomach. Oh...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Which means it’s not transverse myelitis.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: Rapid onset. It could be a perforated ulcer.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Wouldn’t explain the paralysis. Addison’s, from a tumour. It’s possible that I saw his eyelids droop.

utterance.speaker: FOREMAN
utterance.content: We’ve scanned his head five times. You’re bleeding.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: A little thing called a bus crash. It’s just a scalp laceration. It could be hidden in his optic chiasm.

utterance.speaker: FOREMAN
utterance.content: It’s coming from your ear. You think that’s a good thing?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: But that would have affected his eyesight. I need to take a bath.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: Hallucinations and smells were kind of working, right? Why the bath?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Hypnosis gave me a nose picker. Smells set off hallucinations. Sensory deprivation should get the brain into an alpha-theta phase. Didn’t you see Altered States?

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: I don’t think I was even born when that movie was out.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Well then you’re too young to be a doctor. That movie was released in 1980.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: That was twenty-eight years ago.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: No, it wasn’t, shut up.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: Did you just forget what year it is?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: No. I just remembered how old I am. I need to give my brain time to transition so I can embrace my inner monkey. Or maybe I don’t. Give me some physostigmine. It crosses the blood-brain barrier.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: And act like a nerve gas, stop your heart, you’ll go to heaven and be omniscient. Good idea. Not going to happen.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Don’t do anything. Even if I escape. Eat a goat. Get shot by police –

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: Wasn’t born yet means I won’t be entertained by further reference.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: I didn’t know you rode the bus.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I used to drive home after getting drunk, but some mothers got MAD-D. What are you doing here? You weren’t on the bus with me.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Then I guess this isn’t a memory. It’s a fantasy.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: If it’s a fantasy, you’d be wearing... This.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: You’re convinced your patient is dying, and you want to waste your time with a sex fantasy?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Don’t blame me. Blame my gender.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Well, I’m not here to indulge that. I’m here to help you figure out what symptom you saw. Your patient was driving the bus, so all you could see –

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Why can’t you do both?

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Your patient was driving the bus, so all you could see was him sitting down. Most likely facing forward.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: From behind, I saw his earlobes wiggling. Or his head bobbing. But not that.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Could indicate aortic insufficiency.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Marfan’s syndrome.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Or syphilis.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: What if his earlobes were just drooping?

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Ehlers-Danlos?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Or cutis laxa.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: It’s not fatal in adults.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Yeah, yeah, yeah. He’s an adult, very good point. Keep going.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: I’m distracting you.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: No! Dance, woman!

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: You’d rather be diagnosing.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I screamed no.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: And your own subconscious ignored you. Because you’d rather fantasize about finding symptoms. How screwed up is that?

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: Hey, over here. Remember me? I’m the sick guy.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Tell me what I saw.

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: Was it the blood dripping from my ear?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: That doesn’t make sense. Because your shirt wasn’t stained. And because that was me.

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: I could have had a subtle hemiballismus, indicating the early stages of Huntington’s.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Huntington’s wouldn’t explain the abdominal pain. And it’s only on the table because we’re thinking of Thirteen.

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: A shuffling gait could suggest Parkinson’s.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Except there’s no such thing as shuffling sitting.

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: He moved when he helped the old lady up the steps.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Who are you?

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: I’m the answer. Look.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: At what?

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: Here.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You were right.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Help him up.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I got it! It’s Parkinson’s.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: House. Your ear.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Start him on levodopa.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: You should sit down.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: House!

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Get that out of my face.

utterance.speaker: NURSE
utterance.content: Welcome back. I’m Nurse Dickerson.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I don’t need your name. And I got your profession from your super competent technique of melting my retinas.

utterance.speaker: NURSE
utterance.content: Verbal faculties seem to be intact. Do you remember passing out?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I remember puking on Cuddy’s shoes. Ow.

utterance.speaker: NURSE
utterance.content: Yeah. Skull fractures tend to hurt.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: It’d hurt a lot less if you didn’t swipe my pain pills.

utterance.speaker: NURSE
utterance.content: Dr. Cuddy’s orders. Wants me to regulate the amount –

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Wait a second, you brought muscle?

utterance.speaker: NURSE
utterance.content: Dr. Cuddy’s orders.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Means I was wrong. My patient doesn’t have Parkinson’s. Cuddy knows that’s the only reason I wouldn’t want to stay here with my pain pills, porn, and you forever.

utterance.speaker: NURSE
utterance.content: Vomiting means your brain injury is getting worse.

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: House’s skull fracture extends all the way down to his ear canal.

utterance.speaker: FOREMAN
utterance.content: House is being looked after. Our other patient has jaundice, low albumin, and no diagnosis.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: Wilson’s disease.

utterance.speaker: FOREMAN
utterance.content: Thank you. But Wilson’s wouldn’t explain – Foreman.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: How did you eliminate Parkinson’s?

utterance.speaker: FOREMAN
utterance.content: Well, the tests confirmed the abdominal pain was caused by liver failure.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I assume you’ve already ruled out hepatitis and Wilson’s.

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: You should really be resting.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: Give him five minutes. Brainstorming a few possibilities isn’t going to explode his brain.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Then if she’s wrong, that makes this phone call that much more exciting. What about hepatic fibrosis?

utterance.speaker: FOREMAN
utterance.content: Can’t be, his alk-phos was normal.

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: It could be thyrotoxic periodic paralysis.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Did I mention this diagnosis needs to make sense?

utterance.speaker: FOREMAN
utterance.content: Why doesn’t it make sense? The bus driver’s Asian, his potassium is slightly low –

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: If he got paralysed while driving the bus, don’t you think I would have gotten off at the next stop?

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: Not if the next stop was at a 90 degree angle into an SUV.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: The bus would have slowed, I would have noticed –

utterance.speaker: NURSE
utterance.content: Phone call’s over.

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: TPP has all the confirmed symptoms. There’s no downside to testing.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Genetic test is too slow. Run the bagel test!

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: How many more bagels do I have to eat for this to work?

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: High carbs plus exercise is the quickest way to confirm TPP.

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: I’ve been on this for half an hour. I’m not going to collapse again.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: Up the speed.

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: Keep eating.

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: Yeah?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: So the carbo-loading marathon isn’t working. Stop looking around suspiciously. To answer your next two questions, no, I am not there, and yes, you are completely predictable. If the test had worked, you would have called to put my delicate brain at ease.

utterance.speaker: NURSE
utterance.content: I told you not to lock the door.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Still wiping! Put the phone up to bus driver’s grill.

utterance.speaker: NURSE
utterance.content: Who are you talking to?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: My large colon. TPP is not consistent with your patient’s laboured breathing.

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: The patient has laboured breathing because he’s been on a treadmill for the last thirty minutes.

utterance.speaker: NURSE
utterance.content: Did you take my cell phone?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: My large colon did. I’m negotiating its release.

utterance.speaker: BUS DRIVER
utterance.content: Help!

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: What’s happening?

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: The test worked. He collapsed.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You’re half right. He’s wheezing, isn’t he?

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You can’t wheeze without moving your chest muscles. This isn’t TPP.

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: Then what is it?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Well how am I supposed to know? I’m not there!

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: Right heart strain, he’s still not oxygenating.

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: It must be a pulmonary embolism.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: So why haven’t you pushed a vial of tPA?

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: You let him back in?

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: I asked him back in.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: At the tail end of me patiently explaining how you idiots were idiots.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: We pushed tPA ten minutes ago.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: That means it’s not a clot.

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: It has to be a clot. If he had a bagel stuck in his windpipe, I’d have seen it on the echo.

utterance.speaker: FOREMAN
utterance.content: Get him to the OR to suck it out.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Must have just screwed up the intubation. Seal’s good.

utterance.speaker: TAUB
utterance.content: It’s a clot, House.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Wait, wait. Look at his teeth. He’s got shiny new caps. He’s had recent dental surgery.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: You can tell us what that means while we’re rolling him to the OR.

utterance.speaker: THIRTEEN
utterance.content: House!

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: House!

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: House! Oh. Get a syringe.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: I didn’t bring you back here so you could stage a coup!

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Listen to me. Dental air drill pushed an air bubble into his gums. Dislodged while he was driving, and caused a myoclonic jerk. That’s what I must have seen. Then it hit his spine, his liver, and now his lungs.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Dr. Hadley, open the door.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I’m not plumping his pillows here. I’m putting him in the Trendelenburg position to move the bubble to the apex of his heart so you can suck it out, now get the damn syringe.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: I can’t risk you stabbing him in the heart looking for an unconfirmed air bubble.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Stab him.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Dr. Hadley!

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: See? She doesn’t even know your name. Stab his heart!

utterance.speaker: HADLEY
utterance.content: Sat’s at 75.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Yes, he's suffocating.

utterance.speaker: HADLEY
utterance.content: If you’re wrong –

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Shut up and make a decision. You keep standing there, he’s dead either way.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Dr. Hadley!

utterance.speaker: HADLEY
utterance.content: I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Open that door.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Don’t shoot!

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Get him to the OR.

utterance.speaker: HADLEY
utterance.content: The O2 sats. There was an air bubble. He’s okay.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: The other nurse always used to tuck me in.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: I’ll be on the couch. With a shotgun in my lap.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Worrying about me?

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Making sure you don’t try and make a limp for the border. Get some sleep.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I’m not sleepy, Mummy.

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: Me neither.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Who are you? And why are you stalking me?

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: Technically, you’re stalking me.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: What is that? Mosquito?

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: Maybe just a fly.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: In the ointment. So there’s something wrong. There’s some detail I’m not noticing that’s spoiling the big picture.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Is this significant? Or is this dream just going in a different direction now?

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: I guess that depends. What are you going to do with that?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I have to tie this around you.

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: I’m cold.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Stay with me. Why did I say that?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Go away.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: It’s not over. I saved the wrong person.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: This wasn’t just a dream or a fantasy, or a drug-induced trip to Wonderland.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: So the bus driver with the air bubble was just a coincidence?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Nope. I got the causation flipped. The bubble didn’t cause the crash. The crash caused the bubble to dislodge. There was no myoclonic jerk. I saw something else in someone else.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: You’re not leaving.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: What’s the most dangerous thing a patient could do when his brain is on the brink of herniating?

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Elevated heart rate, BP... Which is exactly why you need to stop.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Instead of sleeping, I’m going to be pacing around this apartment trying to decipher those visions.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Why does this matter so much?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I don’t know. Heart rate?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: BP? Contextual memory. I need to get back on that bus with all 31 passengers to remember who and what I saw.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: I’m not going to call in crash victims because you’ve gone insane.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Maybe I don’t need the actual victims.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Who’s playing Anne McKeehan? Right here. Jane Doe 2 from Princeton General. Right here. You two, that’s right. Goth kid. Yeah. At the back on the right. Yeah. Here. Okay...

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: You think that staring at pictures on our shirts is going to be more effective than hypnosis?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Well, if only you’d stop talking, the re-enactment could stimulate activity in my hippocampus and parahippocampal cortex.

utterance.speaker: CAMERON
utterance.content: How long do we have to sit here before you are stimulated?

utterance.speaker: ANN
utterance.content: Stop staring at my breasts. And don’t say or lack thereof.

utterance.speaker: CAMERON
utterance.content: Are you okay? What’d you see?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: It just slipped away.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Is that Vicodin?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Nope. Just a little memory pick-me-up.

utterance.speaker: CAMERON
utterance.content: It’s physostigmine.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Are you crazy? Alzheimer’s drugs will make your brain go into overdrive.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: That’s the point. It’ll speed up my neuronal firing. Turn up the voltage on my memory.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: And blow out your heart. How many did you take?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Just now? Or including the ones I took on the ride over?

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: House, this isn’t worth –

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: House.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Why are you here?

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: You believe in reason above all else. There must be a reason.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You have something to tell me.

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: Yes. Who am I?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: That’s asking, not telling. Who are you?

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: You know who I am.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: If I did, I’d be passed out in bed instead of OD’ing on physostigmine on the 6th Street cross-town.

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: What’s my necklace made of?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Resin.

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: Who am I?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I don’t know. Why the guessing game?

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: Because you don’t know the answer.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: And if I don’t, you don’t. But you know the clues.

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: I know what’s bugging your subconscious. What’s my necklace made of?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: Who am I?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Doesn’t make sense.

utterance.speaker: MYSTERY WOMAN
utterance.content: What’s my necklace made of?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Amber.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I have to tie this around you.

utterance.speaker: AMBER
utterance.content: I’m cold.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Stay with me. Just stay with me.

utterance.speaker: PARAMEDIC
utterance.content: Sir, are you all right? Are you all right? Are you injured anywhere? They’ll take care of you over there.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: He’s coming out of it.

utterance.speaker: KUTNER
utterance.content: Strong pulse.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: You idiot! Your heart stopped.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Amber.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Amber. It was Amber. She was on the bus.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: You almost kill yourself, and all we’re getting is drug-induced fantasies.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Have you spoken to her?

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: She’s probably working. She’s... She’s been on call. I called her... She didn’t call... I... I... How could she...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I don’t know... Jane Doe 2.

utterance.speaker: HADLEY
utterance.content: Female. Late twenties. Kidney damage. Does Amber have a birthmark on her right shoulder blade?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: She was on the bus with me. She’s the one who’s dying.
